abstract: Human rights advisor Andrei Babushkin says that Zaur S Dadayev, main suspect in shooting death of opposition figure Boris Y Nemtsov, was likely forced under duress to confess to crime and that Dadayev and two other suspects suffered multiple injuries in captivity; Russian government questions Babushkin's motives and accuses him of violating laws against hindering investigation of a crime.
lead_paragraph: A member of the Kremlin’s advisory council on human rights said three of the suspects arrested after the death of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov had suffered injuries in captivity.

headline.main: Official Raises Doubts on Confession in Nemtsov Case
headline.print_headline: Official Raises Doubts on Confession in Nemtsov Case

snippet: A member of the Kremlin’s advisory council on human rights said three of the suspects arrested after the death of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov had suffered injuries in captivity.
